The verb is writing. The format and medium are new, but the craft is ancient.

From one of my all-time favourite pieces of inspiration.

I remember you well in the Chelsea Hotel / You were famous, your heart was a legend / You told me again you prefer handsome men / But for me you would make an exception

Have I been listening to The Fame Monster while drinking wine all evening?

You‚Äôre goddamn right I have.

When you‚Äôre feeling low, it‚Äôs amazing what your first meal & coffee of the day can do.

This is why the first thing elderly-mother stereotypes ask is always, ‚Äúhave you eaten?‚Äù
Hmm! Looks like micro.blog does not always include the canonical URL when cross-posting to fbook. Troublesome. Well, this is a work in progress. Will keep fiddling.
If this topic interests you, and assuming fbook even shows you this post (spit), let me know. Happy to discuss. :)

I like that, because if one of those advertising companies goes out of business, or just plain decides my post doesn‚Äôt fit their algorithm, I‚Äôve still got a link I can send anyone and they can go look at it.

This is why phrases like the ‚Äúopen web‚Äù and ‚Äúnet neutrality‚Äù matter.

Broken link that previous post: micro.blog

You can see this post has a canonical URL at a domain I control: danj.ca. So I can make quick, Twitter/Instagram-like posts from my own, and they can be syndicated here, but the content is mine.

So among the reasons I‚Äôm no Facebook fan is my desire to control and own the words I publish and share on the internet. I‚Äôm a supporter of the IndieWeb, but, then again, I can build and host my own websites, so it‚Äôs easy to be.

Here‚Äôs a tool that makes owning your content a bit more accessible: [micro.blog][]. I backed the Kickstarter and am playing around with the service.
